comments.commentBody:
I'm not sure what "tonier suburbs near Boston" you're referring to, but if you have been well-versed on the prices in, say, Brookline, you should know that you won't be able to get any single-family in Brookline east of Chestnut Hill for less than $1m. And you won't find any multi-family at all for less than $1.5m.

Sure, if you move further west, you'll get space on lower prices. But you won't get the convenience and amenities and the ability to walk to everything. But I suppose that's the hidden opportunity costs that you pay.

It's not just all over this country. Just anyone from Australia, for example. These days, prices in those suburbs that used to be cheap and crime-ridden are now all sold by auctions, and people are bidding like crazy. In fact, everything is sold by auctions in cities like Sydney and Melbourne these days. It's totally insane; it reminds me of the days worse than the pre-2007 days here.

If one can afford a second home in Cape Cod or Nantucket, money wouldn't have been an object, would it now. But that doesn't sound like the people noted in the article who are simply looking for a home to stay.

It's really a personal decision that you'd have to ask those who pay these prices. Maybe they're desperate enough to want to stay in the city; maybe their undying love for the city is so great that they have to find a place to live there at all costs. Obviously, that wouldn't be you (or me), since you're asking this question.

I agree with you that the same is happening everywhere with big box stores, etc. But why should I be paying through the nose to live here when a lot of the fabulous freakiness of NYC is rapidly going MIA? I have loud neighbors doing personal training on their rooftop with bad pop music blasting into my bedroom at 6am (other neighbors have complained also); screaming babies on the street from 7am til (gasp) 10pm; building renovating crews drilling/sawing/loud talking all day long; loud, smug conversations wafting up and into my windows daily about money, real estate, babies, babies, babies, food and rachel ray recipes, real estate...and MONEY.This is not why I moved to new york city, these boring conversations about cupcakes is why I left the suburbs in the first place!  I guess the suburban herd mentality is critical mass now and it's tripping in NYC. Patti Smith was right: anyone with an artistic soul would do well to get the eff out of NYC. Now. NYC is no longer a special place, it has become a place for the non-special to exploit. And just yesterday, the Times ran a piece on the allure of Detroit as a mecca for new business creators. Ha!

Patricia: Well you know what they say about the Upper West Side; it's the new Scarsdale.

I have to say that, while I do have some misgivings about Starbucks and would not buy a cappuccino there, I think they (and similar outfits) represent a big improvement over the 70s. I can remember when if you wanted a good European style coffee you had to go to the village. Well, there was one place in Murray Hill and another on the Upper East Side where one could get a decent cappuccino. Also, I can remember the first time, in the late 70s, when I came upon a Duane Reade, on East 46th or so off Fifth. It was quite a revelation. As sick as I am of them now, at the time I considered it a revelation -- a big improvement over Woolworth's and Lamston's.
Are all NYers as provincial and narrow minded as Patricia? References to the suburban herd mentality etc. are so 1990s. Suburbs change, just like cities.

I've lived in nyc for 25 years. Much of it was far from glamorous in a 6th floor walk up. I've also travelled the world. All the Debbie downers talking about the character of the city being gone are not 100% accurate. It's lost some edge and grit (also become much safer) and many of the wonderful mom and pops are gone, but guess what? Same is happening everywhere else. Starbucks, Walgreens are Everywhere! So you don't want to live in an expensive shoebox. No problem. Someone does. Supply and demand. The city is still a vibrant and wonderful place. Come for a visit.

In response to michjas from Phoenix, there was a time when living in Manhattan (rather than a tony suburb, for example) needed no explanation or justification because Manhattan was such an exciting, diverse, and affordable place. How could you not want to live there... But it's changed.  It has become a cold, forbidding, glass skyscraper canyon for the rich and ultra'rich, and whether you want to live there or not is not even relevant because you probably can't afford it!
The square footage of one bedrooms I have seen in Tudor City is less than the square footage of many studios.

The original owners of most of those buildings have been gone for a very very long time -- since long before the buildings were gutted or gentrified, since Harlem is a pretty old neighborhood. When the original owners bought or built their homes Harlem was a pretty nice place.

"I think having land and not ruining it is the most beautiful art that anybody could ever want to own."

--Andy Warhol

NJ Independent, have you noticed that in most places with high property taxes, there is also a high rate of students going on to four-year colleges?

The current property tax, taxing both land and buildings at the same millage rate, is inferior to land value taxation (which Milton Friedman maintained -- 1978, 2006, and in between) is the "least bad" tax. But even the conventional property tax is far superior to sales taxes or wage taxes for funding public goods.

you really live in a bubble don't you? The median income of Manhattan (not the wealthiest borough, but close) is 64k USD. Middle class, if you are being generous then, ranges from something like 40k to 100k USD for a family. If you have the money to for a 1 million dollar apartment, you are not middle class, not even by NYC standards. You are wealthy. You have a family income of at least 250k a year, and probably significantly more than that. You are in the top few percent of New York City.

It's not a boohoo thing, you just sound horribly insulated and ignorant of the situation of your fellow New Yorkers, surrounded by people with middle 6 figure incomes and thinking you are middle class because your friends have the same income as you.

Real estate taxes are 40% of my coop apartment building's budget -- slightly more than the next two largest expense items (labor and mortgage debt service) combined -- and they have been increasing faster than other large expense categories in recent years.

Meanwhile, NYC gouges homeowners with real estate tax (my tax - we live in a financial district coop - has more than doubled since 2009). Great, you say, you can afford it? Not for long, and neither can the vast number of other truly middle class people living in this city, who bought before, say, 10 years ago. They are being forced out.

If NY is interested in keeping its middle class, decreasing Manhattan RE tax would be a great start (and for revenue, consider some increase in the boroughs - why should a $1M apt in Brooklyn or Queens pay 10 or 20% of the tax that it would in Manhattan?)

So many commenters have stated "move somewhere cheaper" and "boo-hoo". For some sure, but for most, that's an impossibility for most - where are millions of people to go? Jobs are here, lives are here, etc. Perhaps, just maybe, eventually employers will go elsewhere, and the city may (is already) undercutting the vitality that made it so attractive to start with - real people, not non-occupying owners.

And for the boo-hoo crowd, try to get this - middle class in NYC often means a family/combined income of 6 figures not starting with a 1. Throw in that RE tax, city, state, and federal taxes, etc., and that gets trimmed by MORE than 50%. So your sympathy could indeed go out to someone who is struggling to find a (gasp) $1M 2-br apt - they're not rich by NYC standards.

I believe the problem of the nonresident megmarich buying here is overstated, and I live in  a neighborhood where they have a pretty strong presence. I think there are many things to blame. Some others, aside from the megarich, include: the popularity of a variety of TV shows, from "Sex and the City" to "Girls;" the pervasiveness of lifestyle gossip and lifestyle gossip media;  the cleaning up and sanitizing of the city, which made it much more appealing as a permanent abode for a variety of people, ranging from  40-something otherwise-suburban Jewish Mother Germophobes to Frat Bro's and Sorority Gals to Republicans to Elder Hostelers and on and on. Some of these are permanent residents and some are not. Some are rich and some are not (although they may have rich parents subsidizing them).

Save the Farms:

"...but maybe the voice of the people is needed for the Democrats to realize this."

***

The president has a very tenuous relationship with reality. We know what he believed before the ACA was implemented. We now know what he believes about these enrollment numbers.

In his mind, it's working well, but he appears to learn the hard way. It took a major and very public failure to get him to notice the federal health care exchange was not functional. He actually thought the problem was a few glitches. Then site visits were counted as enrollments. It took him some time to realize there were some very significant problems. Finally, he got it.

He is now just as out of touch about the churning taking place among health insurance enrollments. It's entirely possible he really has no idea what those numbers mean. So, yes, the voters will explain it to him.
And what else the Boeing management did was to screw the workers and betray Seattle for the executive convenience of Chicago.  I always wondered why they adopted those attitudes.  Now I know.

If you click on the "eyepiece" link in that article,
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eyepiece

you will learn that the lens closest to the eye, of the several lenses in an eyepiece, is the "eye lens."

For instance:
"The eye needs to be held at a certain distance behind the eye lens of an eyepiece to see images properly through it."

I was raised as an atheist and holidays have never been an issue, especially Easter or Christmas.  Bunnies and eggs are all about fertility and spring.  Santa never threatened to indoctrinate us with any specific theism.  The challenge I have is not doing a spit take while our public school recites the "under god" part of the pledge.  My partner has made me promise not to nit-pick that while our kid is so young.  I feel really good that my kid choses to say "one nation under glob."  That seems to make us all happy.
Francesca R:  And Santa Claus is going to come down your chimney on Christmas Eve with a bag full of gifts, right?
Then they should refuse to participate.  Allowing someone else to make your trial decisions is against the code of ethics.

Mr. Jencks is misinformed. Most of the prosecution team is civilian not military. And all of them, military and civilian, are aware (directly or impliedly) of the Agency control over the process.  There are no knaves.
Thomas, but who among us doesn't think "the person and 'persons' who most need it" is always the other guy?

I hope it's obvious to everyone that Mr. Nocera doesn't think this is a lesson only about aircraft.  And it's a good lesson, which the persons and "persons" who most need it will refuse to learn (a prediction).

Adaptation to hatchery environments is the least of worries for fish without rivers.  If they don't have rivers, they can't live anywhere but hatcheries (plus wherever those hatcheries can bus them to).

The hydropower is secondary to agriculture.  The Klamath, Trinity, Sacramento, Pit, Feather, and American river ecosystems have all suffered for the benefit of the billions of dollars brought in by agribusiness in the Central Valley, not to mention populating arid, semi-arid, and desert regions in Southern California.  Future generations will ask: 'what were they thinking?'.
Sorry, but you're misinformed. Why do you think the oil companies are making such a huge fuss about this pipeline if they have other ways to get this oil to market?

We USED to do things differently in Canada. But that was before Harper and his neocons and Al berta oil cartel took over the country. Canada has lost utterly its reputation as a peacekeeping and environmentally progressive nation.

And it's fine to sit in Toronto and tell the people in BC to shut up and drink their bitumin, but they may not be so keen to do that just to enrich the Alberta oil and Toronto banking industries.
Yes so the oil can be shipped via Warren buffet's railroad.
Please, let it languish FOREVER!

The pipeline is nothing but trouble for the US and its environment and its treasury. No revenue or benefits to be gained by the nation but just trouble and and un-taxed profits from the oil companies and Canada.
Lets them build their pipeline in their country...

I agree. Just don't go into the election thinking that the opposition comes from well meaning people who want to see all Americans covered but are just unhappy with the details of the program. There is a dog whistle hear and while it is not often articulated, the truth is that  many opponents of the law don't like it precisely because it is providing previously uninsured and unworthy  black and brown (maybe some Muslims) with coverage that is being subsidized by tax dollars being provided by white middle class and working class people.

Democrats need to concentrate on getting out their constituents to vote, selling Democratic achievements, and pointing out where Republicans fall short (failing to grow the economy, opposing equal pay for women, approving of Citizens United).

As for the ACA: there's nothing wrong with providing people with affordable health care-- it's an achievement of which to be proud.

When you buy real estate you are made aware of and agree to covenants. So "probably hardly anybody even knew" does not cut it. But it does work for people who like to decide which rules and law to follow and which to ignore.
